citation.article-title: Mycobacterium brumae sp. nov., a Rapidly Growing Nonphotochromogenic Mycobacterium.

p.s: Description of Mycobacterium brumae sp. nov.
Mycobacterium brumae (bru'mae. L. gen. n. brumae, of winter, referring to the time of year at which the first strains were isolated)
The cells of M. brumae are gram-positive rods, 2.0 to 2.5 μm long and 0.3 to 0.5 μm wide; they are mostly strongly acid fast, except for a small number (less than 10%) of cyanophil forms.
Smears prepared from Youmans medium (without Tween 80) and Middlebrook 7H12 medium contain clumps or cords.
Colonies on Löwenstein-Jensen medium and on Middlebrook 7H10 agar are eugonic, rough, and nonpigmented in the dark or after exposure to light.
Growth occurs within 5 days at 30 and 37°C but not at 45°C.
The type strain produces thermostable catalase and is positive for β-glucosidase, nitrate reductase, penicillinase, trehalase, urease, and iron uptake.
Tween 80 is hydrolyzed after 10 days; niacin is not produced, and salicylate is not degraded to catechol.
No growth occurs on MacConkey agar without crystal violet.
Glucose, meso-inositol, fructose, and sodium citrate are utilized as sole carbon sources in the presence of ammoniacal nitrogen.
Acid is produced from glucose, fructose, meso-inositol, and trehalose but not from L-arabinose, dulcitol, mannitol, L-rhamnose, and D-xylose.

Growth is inhibited by sodium chloride (5%), hydroxylamine (500 mdliter), D-cycloserine (30 mg/liter), ethambutol (2 mg/liter), kanamycin (20 mg/liter), capreomycin (40 mg/liter), and isoniazid (10 mg/liter).
Tuberculostearate is detected by gas chromatography; docosanoate is a mycolic acid cleavage product.
Secondary alcohols are not detected. M. brumae contains only α-mycolates (68 to 76 carbon atoms long), which release only docosanoate after pyrolysis.
